WorkItem.Description: It's not easy from an internet search to locate an up-to-date, "official" version of typescript-mode.el. Shouldn't this be part of the TypeScript project? (Apologies if it is and I couldn't find it.)

Comments.Message:
There is no 'official' Emacs or Vim support.  There were some initial versions at TypeScript release created by a partner team, but the TypeScript team does not maintain or ship support for these editors.  

There are a great number of excellent and popular editors out there.  This is an area where we'd love to see the community help provide support.

The community is active, but we're lacking information/coordination from the TypeScript team.

As far as I know, the "partner team" editor support for TS was limited to syntax highlighting. Still, since they were released, I had hoped that they would be maintained, following the TS language development.

The typescript-tools project is making the (nice, if underdocumented) TS language services available to editor plugins for Vim, Emacs and Sublime (https://github.com/clausreinke/typescript-tools). This gives us IDE-style functionality on top of the basic syntax highlighting.

Are you saying that the syntax highlighting is completely abandoned/unsupported? Or is that partner team still active and reachable somewhere? I don't want to duplicate existing work, and I don't recall seeing a license (it was distributed as a "sample").

Worth also mentioning that the existing Emacs modes are not only out of date, but baroque (3.5k lines of Elisp, probably enough to write a compiler :) and buggy (see [this issue](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18968095/functioning-up-to-date-emacs-mode-for-typescript) I raised on Stack Overflow).
